sub_topic: Calculation of the Gibbs free energy change for an electrochemical reaction
message_1:
What is the Gibbs free energy change at standard conditions for the electrochemical reaction of zinc (Zn) and copper (Cu) given the following half-cell reactions:

Zn(s) --> Zn2+(aq) + 2e-
Cu2+(aq) + 2e- --> Cu(s)

The standard reduction potential for the Cu2+(aq) + 2e- --> Cu(s) half-cell reaction is +0.34 V, and for the Zn2+(aq) + 2e- --> Zn(s) half-cell reaction is -0.76 V.
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) for the electrochemical reaction, we first need to determine the overall cell potential (E°cell) by combining the two half-cell reactions:

Zn(s) --> Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻  (E° = -0.76 V)
Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ --> Cu(s)  (E° = +0.34 V)
---------------------------------------------
Zn(s) + Cu²⁺(aq) --> Zn²⁺(aq) + Cu(s)

Now, we can calculate the overall cell potential (E°cell) by subtracting the standard reduction potential of the anode (Zn) from the standard reduction potential of the cathode (Cu):

E°cell = E°cathode - E°anode
E°cell = (+0.34 V) - (-0.76 V)
E°cell = +1.10 V

Next, we can use the Nernst equation to calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) at standard conditions:

ΔG° = -nFE°cell

where n is the number of moles of electrons transferred in the reaction (in this case, n = 2), F is the Faraday constant (approximately 96,485 C/mol), and E°cell is the overall cell potential.

ΔG° = -(2 mol)(96,485 C/mol)(+1.10 V)
ΔG° = -212,267 J/mol

So, the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) for the electrochemical reaction of zinc and copper at standard conditions is -212,267 J/mol.
